citations.narrative:
One nest box within the Macaw Aviary is in need of repairs. The wooden nest box had sharp edges and points along the
front opening, with multiple screws exposed and protruding below this area. Compromised structural integrity within
primary enclosures can provide an opportunity for entrapment or injury to the animals contained therein. Housing facilities
shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the birds from injury and securely contain
them.
Correct by July 25, 2024.

The facility did not have complete acquisition records. Required information was missing for one Eland, one Bison, and
one Yak. Acquisition and disposition records, including offspring born at the facility and all records of disposition, are
necessary to accurately track and identify animals being used in regulated activities, as well as aid in the detection of
movement of animals upon relocation to a new site.
The facility shall make, keep and maintain records that fully and correctly include all the required acquisition and
disposition information, including: the name and address of the person from whom the animals were acquired, the USDA
license number of the person if licensed or the vehicle license number and state and driver’s license number and state if
not licensed, the name and address of the person to whom an animal was given/sold, the date of acquisition or
disposition, the species of animal and the number of animals involved.
Correct by July 25, 2024.

While observing at least seven separate private vehicles moving throughout the drive-through park at the facility during a
full days’ inspection, the inspector could not locate any readily identifiable attendants present during public interactions
with the animals. Though one park ranger was observed once in the drive-through park during the inspection, they were
unable to oversee all of the patrons present during this time. This resulted in unattended periods of public contact and
feeding of the animals housed therein.
The lack of attendants present during times of public contact increases the risk of injury to patrons and/or animals. A
responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant must be present at all times during periods of
public contact.
Correct by July 22, 2024.

Chemical agents used for cleaning and disinfecting were stored on a table beside the outdoor enclosure housing three
brown lemurs. The table was stationed alongside the enclosure fencing itself and within reach of the lemurs to grab. In
addition, bags of unopened commercial primate food were stored on the floor and directly against the wall under a table in
the Nutrition Building.
Cleaning supplies contain ingredients that can be toxic if ingested, resulting in great harm to nonhuman primates. Storing
supplies of food off the ground and away from walls lessens the substrates’ exposure to contamination, vermin, and
unintended compromise. Supplies of food and bedding must be stored off the floor and away from the walls, to allow
cleaning underneath and around the supplies. Open bedding supplies not in use must be kept in leakproof containers with
tightly fitting lids to prevent spoilage and contamination. Substances that are toxic to nonhuman primates, but are required
for normal husbandry practices, must not be stored in food storage and preparation areas unless kept in cabinets.
Correct by July 23, 2024.

The enclosures housing one dromedary camel and one African Watusi did not offer sufficient shelter to accommodate
these animals. The facility is in the process of completing renovations in the Backyard pen, housing one Watusi during the
inspection. As a result, the new shelter structure provided shade, but lacked provisions to provide protection from
inclement weather conditions and elements. Additionally, one dromedary camel was temporarily housed outdoors along
the backside of the barn to facilitate halter training. The facility stated the training takes place for a few hours before the
camel is returned to its permanent primary enclosure. However, this area only offered a ledge off the side of the barn,
lacking the ability to provide adequate shelter conditions.
Inadequate protection from weather conditions can lead to overheating, discomfort, or increased exposure in extreme
temperatures and elements. All animals must be provided with shelter to prevent discomfort and provide protection from
local climatic conditions.
Correct by July 25, 2024.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
Upon inspection, one Parakeet was undergoing medical treatment, resulting in the bird being individually housed and
unable to see or hear birds of their own or compatible species. The facility had not implemented additional considerations
to accommodate the Parakeet while housed in a separate barn away from the Parakeet Aviary.
Implementing enrichment protocols for special consideration categories ensure sufficient conditions are in place to
promote the psychological well-being of the impacted birds at the facility. Certain birds must be provided special attention
regarding enhancement of their environment, based on the needs of the individual species and/or individual bird, in
accordance with the instructions of the attending veterinarian. Special considerations must be included in the plan for
individually housed social species of birds that are unable to see or hear other birds of their own or compatible species.
Correct by July 23, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives and licensee.
n

narrative:
3.150(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
One nest box within the Macaw Aviary is in need of repairs. The wooden nest box had sharp edges and points along the 
front opening, with multiple screws exposed and protruding below this area. Compromised structural integrity within 
primary enclosures can provide an opportunity for entrapment or injury to the animals contained therein. Housing facilities 
shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the birds from injury and securely contain 
them.  
Correct by July 25, 2024. 
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility did not have complete acquisition records. Required information was missing for one Eland, one Bison, and 
one Yak. Acquisition and disposition records, including offspring born at the facility and all records of disposition, are 
necessary to accurately track and identify animals being used in regulated activities, as well as aid in the detection of 
movement of animals upon relocation to a new site.  
The facility shall make, keep and maintain records that fully and correctly include all the required acquisition and 
disposition information, including: the name and address of the person from whom the animals were acquired, the USDA 
license number of the person if licensed or the vehicle license number and state and driver’s license number and state if 
not licensed, the name and address of the person to whom an animal was given/sold, the date of acquisition or 
disposition, the species of animal and the number of animals involved.  
Correct by July 25, 2024. 
2.131(d)(2) 
   
Handling of animals. 
While observing at least seven separate private vehicles moving throughout the drive-through park at the facility during a 
full days’ inspection, the inspector could not locate any readily identifiable attendants present during public interactions 
with the animals. Though one park ranger was observed once in the drive-through park during the inspection, they were 
unable to oversee all of the patrons present during this time. This resulted in unattended periods of public contact and 
feeding of the animals housed therein. 
The lack of attendants present during times of public contact increases the risk of injury to patrons and/or animals. A

responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant must be present at all times during periods of 
public contact. 
Correct by July 22, 2024. 
3.75(e) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Chemical agents used for cleaning and disinfecting were stored on a table beside the outdoor enclosure housing three 
brown lemurs. The table was stationed alongside the enclosure fencing itself and within reach of the lemurs to grab. In 
addition, bags of unopened commercial primate food were stored on the floor and directly against the wall under a table in 
the Nutrition Building. 
Cleaning supplies contain ingredients that can be toxic if ingested, resulting in great harm to nonhuman primates. Storing 
supplies of food off the ground and away from walls lessens the substrates’ exposure to contamination, vermin, and 
unintended compromise. Supplies of food and bedding must be stored off the floor and away from the walls, to allow 
cleaning underneath and around the supplies. Open bedding supplies not in use must be kept in leakproof containers with 
tightly fitting lids to prevent spoilage and contamination. Substances that are toxic to nonhuman primates, but are required 
for normal husbandry practices, must not be stored in food storage and preparation areas unless kept in cabinets. 
Correct by July 23, 2024. 
3.127(b) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The enclosures housing one dromedary camel and one African Watusi did not offer sufficient shelter to accommodate 
these animals. The facility is in the process of completing renovations in the Backyard pen, housing one Watusi during the 
inspection. As a result, the new shelter structure provided shade, but lacked provisions to provide protection from 
inclement weather conditions and elements. Additionally, one dromedary camel was temporarily housed outdoors along 
the backside of the barn to facilitate halter training. The facility stated the training takes place for a few hours before the 
camel is returned to its permanent primary enclosure. However, this area only offered a ledge off the side of the barn, 
lacking the ability to provide adequate shelter conditions.  
Inadequate protection from weather conditions can lead to overheating, discomfort, or increased exposure in extreme 
temperatures and elements. All animals must be provided with shelter to prevent discomfort and provide protection from 
local climatic conditions. 
Correct by July 25, 2024. 
3.154(c)(4) 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
Upon inspection, one Parakeet was undergoing medical treatment, resulting in the bird being individually housed and 
unable to see or hear birds of their own or compatible species. The facility had not implemented additional considerations 
to accommodate the Parakeet while housed in a separate barn away from the Parakeet Aviary. 
Implementing enrichment protocols for special consideration categories ensure sufficient conditions are in place to 
promote the psychological well-being of the impacted birds at the facility. Certain birds must be provided special attention 
regarding enhancement of their environment, based on the needs of the individual species and/or individual bird, in 
accordance with the instructions of the attending veterinarian. Special considerations must be included in the plan for

individually housed social species of birds that are unable to see or hear other birds of their own or compatible species. 
Correct by July 23, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives and licensee.

species.common: CONGO AFRICAN GREY PARROT / GRAY PARROT
